brief_summary.textblock:
Lactose, one of the key nutrients in human milk may be critically important to infants for
      more reasons than being a source of energy. We are interested in understanding how lactose
      when compared to other sugars influences how nutrients, specifically macronutrients are
      handled after digestion and absorption. To date, there have been no studies looking at how
      fat and protein varies when lactose compared to other sugars is ingested. There may be
      metabolic advantages to considering lactose for nutrition support of premature infants
      rather than glucose or dextrose as is often used in intravenous feeds, or the corn syrup
      solids in lactose-free formulas. We hope the information from this study will provide new
      information on the unique aspects of lactose.

      Hypothesis: The hypothesis is that providing carbohydrate as lactose:

        1. minimizes the amount of carbohydrate that is converted into fat

        2. enables a relatively constant metabolic state throughout feeding interval that avoids
           swings of high to low insulin, glucose, and fats.

clinical_study.condition: Focus of Study: Oral Tolerance Test With Glucose, Lactose, Sucrose

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  male

          -  at least 19 years of age

          -  body mass index (BMI) between 18.5 and 25

          -  fasting blood glucose level < 6.1 mmol/L (110 mg/dL) measured by glucometer on the
             day of the study and

          -  comfortable speaking, reading and understanding English

          -  comfortable drinking at least one cup (250 ml) of milk

          -  non-smoking

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  not willing to provide blood samples, have

          -  impaired lactose or glucose tolerance,

          -  pre-diabetes, diabetes mellitus and any other endocrine disorder,

          -  coronary heart disease, liver function test abnormalities or any chronic disease

          -  routinely take medications, including aspirin, cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors, statins
             and fish oil

          -  consuming more than 1 alcoholic drink per day

clinical_study.official_title: Lactose: A Unique Carbohydrate Enabling Homeostatic Regulation of Blood Glucose & Insulin

overall_official.affiliation: University of British Columbia, Child & Family Research Institute

primary_outcome.description: Area under the curve changes in the outcome measures following oral ingestion.
primary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma insulin, glucagon, triglycerides and amino acids.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Area under the curve analyses of changes in plasma fatty acids following oral ingestion
secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma fatty acids.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor)
